member.name: T:Commands
member.summary:
The methods in this Commands class is the class that is called from PerfView 'UserCommand DLLNAME.Method'
Commands can have varags (params argument qualifier) and can also have default arguments.
To use them: PerfView UserCommand METHODNAME arg1 arg2 ...

member.name: M:Commands.DemoCommandWithDefaults(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: A quick example of a command that has default arguments. You can also use the 'params' style varargs.
member.param: A demo of a required argument
A demo of a optional argument
A demo of a optional argument

member.name: M:Commands.DemoHtmlReport(System.String[])
member.summary: This command creates a simple HTML report that has links that in turn cause actions. If you make custom reports you are likely to want to do this.
member.param: a list of strings that will appear in the report

member.name: M:Commands.DemoLoadLibrary(System.String)
member.summary: This demo scans a particular ETL file for a strongly typed events (in this case Image Load events) and prints them out.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoEventSearch(System.String)
member.summary: This demo scans a particular ETL file for events of a particular type (in this case PerfView events) and prints them to the log.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoOpenPerfViewXml(System.String)
member.summary: A trivial example of opening a PerfView XML file and then displaying it in the viewer.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoOpenCpuStacks(System.String)
member.summary: Trivial demo that opens an ETL file named 'eltFileName' and opens the view on the CPU data.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoOpenEventView(System.String)
member.summary:
If you wish to programatically get at events in the ETL file you typically will want to use the etlFile.TraceLog.Events directly (they are more efficient). This is what is done in the DemoEventSearch, DemoLoadLibrary, and DemoStartupReport cases.
However if you simply want to control the PerfView event viewer and open it, then using the etlFile.Events class is what you want since you can open the event viewer on it easily.
In this demo, we open a viewer for just the process and image load events.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoStartupReport(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Here is an example of a 'real' report. It computes startup statistics for a given process.
member.param: The name of the process to focus on. If not present, the first process to start is used.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoStacksReportByDll(System.String,System.String,System.String[])
member.summary:
This demonstrates how to use the CallTree view problematically. This demo takes a set of DLL names, and then assigns all CPU time to whichever member of the set is hit first crawling from the IP to the top of the stack.
The idea is that you want to 'blame' one of small set of DLLs, and you want to ignore all other dlls that are not in your set (e.g. OS dlls), and assign any time they had one in your set.
member.param: The name of the process to focus on (null means first pr
The list of DLLs names (file names without extensions) to blame.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoCommandWithQualifiers(System.String[])
member.summary: Commands with many options need more complex argument parsing, which is what 'CommandLineParser does. Here is an example of adding two optional qualifiers as well as parameters.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoConfigSettings(System.String)
member.summary: This routine demos the use of the 'ConfigData' to save state across invokations of the perfView program.
member.param: A value to remember between invokations

member.name: M:Commands.DemoMemoryGraph
member.summary: This demo shows you how to create a a graph of memory and turn it into a stackSource with MemoryGraphStackSource.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoInternStackSource
member.summary:
This demo shows you how to create a StackSource (or a class Stacks from 'nothing').
Note that a useful alternative to this is to simply generate a file XML file which matches the format of a PerfVIew.XML file. This XML file is just what you would expect (a list of frame definitions, which define stacks which define samples). Thus you may wish to simply generate this XML directy and simple read that file with OpenPerfViewXmlFile

member.name: M:Commands.GetTraceEventsWithProcessFilter(PerfViewExtensibility.ETLDataFile)
member.summary: Gets the TraceEvents list of events from etlFile, applying a process filter if the /process argument is given.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoOnStartup
member.summary:
If you place a file called PerfViewExtensions\PerfViewStartup next to the PerfView.exe it will run execute commands in that file. If you put
OnStartup DemoOnStartup
It will execute this user command when PerfView starts up.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoOnFileOpen(System.String)
member.summary:
If you place a file called PerfViewExtensions\PerfViewStartup next to the PerfView.exe it will run execute commands in that file. If you put
OnFileOpen .etl DemoOnFileOpen
It will execute this user command whenever a file is opened. This allows you to manipulate the views for this file type. It is passed the name of the file that was opened.

member.name: M:Commands.DemoDeclareFileView(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
If you place a file called PerfViewExtensions\PerfViewStartup next to the PerfView.exe it will run execute commands in that file. If you put
DeclareFileView .etl "Demo View In Etl File" DemoDeclareFileView
It will create a child node for all .etl files called 'Demo View In Etl File' If you click on this node it will execute this user command. It is passed the name of the file that was opened and the name of the view that was opened (in this case 'Demo View In Etl File').

member.name: T:Commands.MyStackSource
member.summary: InternStackSource is used to create a StackSource out of nothing. However at least currently you need to subclass it to get at the creation APIs.
